title: CTRL0000051197 - Transcribed Interview of Thomas Paul Conover, (March 8, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held in Room 4480, O'Neill House Office
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is a transcribed interview of Thomas Paul Conover, conducted by the House
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
And I apologize if I mispronounced your last
M r . - This will be a staff-led interview.
And members may join -- I don't
see any on right now, but if they join, they are also able to ask questions.
, and in the room with me today
At this time, could counsel please state your name for the record?
There is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
We also -- yeah, that's it for who we have.
until each question is completed before you begin your response, and we will try to wait
until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head, so it is important that you
answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
question is not clear, please ask for clarification.
If you do not know the answer, just say
And then just a couple of things to note other than that.
First, it's important that you understand that this interview is voluntary.
time you would like to stop speaking with us, that is your choice.
point you need to discuss something with your attorney in private, please let us know,
and we will take a break so you can have that conversation.
Second, this interview is not under oath, but because this is a formal congressional
investigation, as we tell all of our witnesses, you are obligated under Federal law to tell
the truth, the same as if you were speaking with the FBI or the Department of Justice.
It is unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
interview, providing false information could result in criminal penalties for false
Third, you are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and
us, including the prosecutor or judge in your case, or you can tell no one at all.
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with
Fourth, the select committee is separate and independent from the Department
with the select committee in its investigation.
We have no involvement with the prosecutions, and DOJ is not a partner
The select committee also is not a party to your criminal case and is not agreeing
to submit anything on your behalf to the judge, nor can we make any representation
whether, if you tell the judge you met with us, that the judge will be more favorable to
Fifth, we have agreed with Ms. Wagner not to share the substance of what you
say with the Department of Justice prior to your sentencing, but there are two possible
was unaware of or if we had reason to believe you lied during this interview, then we
would be obligated to tell the Department of Justice or another appropriate law
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we thought law enforcement
And if you tell the judge that you met with us, please understand that may prompt
questions from the judge about what you said and whether it is consistent with your prior
we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
And if the judge starts asking questions,
And, just logistically, let us know if you need any breaks or you would ever like to
take a pause and discuss something with Ms. Wagner.
mute, go off record for a little bit so you two can have that conversation in private.
If that's the case, we would
And if there's ever a moment where
or I ask a question at the same
time and you can't hear us or, like I said, we're not clear, just let us know, and we will ask
And any questions before we begin, Ms. Wagner?
And where do you currently live?
Have you always lived in Keller, Texas?
So we'll start off with just a little bit of background information.
I grew up in Irving and moved to Hurst and then to Keller.
in the same area, same 25-mile radius for my entire life.
I went to one semester of college.
I fix hail damage on cars.
Is that your only job currently or --
Now we're going to talk a little bit about the lead-up to January 6th.
So, in general, how would you describe your level of political engagement during
And what is your educational background?
And what do you do for a living?
former President Trump's first term, so, like, 2016 to right before the 2020 election?
I'd never really been politically active.
I went to one rally that he had with
my mother in Dallas, and then I went to January 6th.
I've ever done, other than, you know, maybe Face book or something.
been active in any kind of politics other than that.
That's the only real political things
Did you pay a lot of attention to politics during former
I mean, it was all over the news, so yeah.
I would have to say all of the above.
And when you say "news," was that television?
Talking about the news specifically, so on the television, did you pay
attention to local news or national news or both?
One or the other more so, or --
No, I tried to be balanced.
I watched CNN, MSNBC, FOX, the local channels.
In terms of internet sources, were those newspapers or other print media online?
Yeah, I would say, like, Yahoo or MSN, CNN, FOX, kind of the same things.
And did you read print publications too?
We don't have a lot of papers.
Like, if I was at a
hotel or something like that and they had a free newspaper, then, yes, sir.
So I'm going to list off a bunch of social media applications that might be used for
news, and just, you know, let me know if you've used them.
I think I tried to get an account and it didn't work.
And just so I can orient you again, we're talking before the 2020
No, I didn't have Parler before the 2020 election.
Maybe if it was used as a source on one of the other ones.
I think I opened up an account after the election, but, no, I don't really get
Did you watch a lot of news on VouTube?
Did you ever look at thedonald.win?
I've got an account, but I never could figure Twitter out.
So, considering that list of social media sites, news sites, or news aggregate sites,
did you use any of them more than the others?
Would you say that you got a lot of political information from any social
I don't really trust social media.
I mean, you see stuff, but -- you
So, to clarify, you mentioned a bunch of news sources earlier.
Were you going to those websites independently or were you finding those articles on
I find -- I have CNN, MSNBC, Yahoo, MSN.com, those are all
on my -- either in the Yahoo thing on my phone or an actual app.
Like I said, I'm not real
tech-savvy, so a lot of that stuff you said earlier, I have no idea what it is.
Did you ever follow former President Trump on social media?
Again, I think I probably tried to on Twitter, but I didn't get that.
remember if I was on his Facebook or not.
been on his Facebook, but I didn't -- I didn't Facebook to him.
So fair to say that, even if you did follow him, it wasn't something
you were paying close attention to?
I paid more close attention to, like I said, the FOX News, CNN, MSNBC,
Yahoo, MSN.com, kind of the major ones, like ABC local, CBS.
So would you say, then, that the 2020 election, did that change your political
So, right after the 2020 election, did you think that the election was
I did not think it was stolen from President Trump.
one of the dumbest things I ever heard.
So I guess, then, after the 2020 election, did you participate in any rallies or any
And I've been to nothing else since then, no.
And, like I said, the only other
thing that I'd ever been to was a rally that Trump had in Dallas, and I believe that was the
So, just for the record, then, you did not attend either the November 14th
rally in Washington, D.C., or the December 12th rally in Washington, D.C., to contest the
And I assume the answer to this is "no," but for the record:
election and up until January 6th, were you making any political donations to groups that
Any political donations I ever made I believe were to the Trump
campaign or the RNC, and not a lot of that.
So, then, at the beginning of December 2020, how would you describe your, sort
Not -- didn't really have a whole lot.
You know, I'd get on Facebook and
mouth off a little bit, but, I mean, I'm not a -- I never went to, like, rallies or stood on
street corners or anything like that.
Well, were you thinking a lot about politics at that time?
something that came to mind a lot?
Why don't we talk a little bit, then, about factors that might've influenced your
decision to travel to Washington, D.C., for the January 6th rally.
Can you tell me what you were -- like, what was your reasoning for wanting to go
Well, the whole thing started off -- as I said, I do paintless dent repair.
We're a group of guys that travels all over, chasing hail storms.
people from all over the country.
Originally, there was supposed to be six or eight of us that were going.
figured we were going to go to the hotel, you know, have some drinks, eat, maybe play
some cards, and go to the rally the next day.
that it ended up just being two of us going.
So let's back up a little bit.
It wasn't until probably 2 days before that
When did you decide to go to Washington, D.C., for
I don't even think we talked about it until maybe a week or two before that
we have a -- you know, we all talk on Facebook, and that's all -- that's really all I
And I could be wrong with that.
There was going to be a handful of guys going.
And I know that I -- I believe I called the hotel couple days before we left to make
sure that their bar was open and the restaurant.
And, at that time, they were.
Do you remember why your group wanted to go to Washington, D.C.?
More of a curiosity factor, I guess.
And, like I said, we do -- our gig is kind of -- you know, it's when it hails.
there's a lot of times where, the winter, you know, we hunt.
I generally, before COVID, in January, I leave for Australia and I work in Australia,
because our winter is their summer.
So I usually go over there and work 3 or 4 months.
So, pre-COVID, I wouldn't have even been in town January 6th.
Did you want to go to Washington, D.C., because -- let me rephrase.
Did you know that on January 6th Congress would be certifying the electoral count
in the Presidential election for Joe Biden?
I think I figured that out when I got there, but it wasn't really on the -- that's
So I've pulled up your statement of facts from your docket, and it seems you had a
conversation with someone named Blakely on December 12th, 2020.
He's in my -- we're in the same business.
Is he one of the six or eight people that you referenced earlier that
you thought you were going to D.C. with?
He was the one that I ended up going with.
So, on December 12th -- I'm going to read to you from here.
So Blakely says, "No don't tar and feather go to Washington on the 6th of January
"I'm planning on flying in on the 5th and returning the 7th
I didn't realize -- I do now.
I didn't realize that it was that many weeks
So, then, you were talking with -- were you just talking with Blakely or were
you talking with the whole group in early December about going to Washington, D.C.?
He was telling me that some other people were going, and I think -- I think
that I remember seeing some of the other guys saying on Face book that they were going.
But I know that that came up in conversations that me and Blakely had.
Why did you think it was important to be in Washington, D.C., on
winter, it was cold, it was boring.
I mean, I had no real preconceived notions.
I wasn't working at the time.
No, I couldn't speak to him.
Do you know where Blakely got the idea?
But I would assume that it was -- people were
But, no, I don't really get -- I really don't know why his -- what prompted him
What did you think he meant when he was talking about tarring and
feathering and, you know, not sitting around, going to actually D.C.?
He's kind of a smart aleck like me.
What do you mean by that?
He's just kind of a smart aleck.
I didn't honestly believe that he wanted to
But he does say -- and this is
I guess -- I can't speak to what he says, but I didn't really take that as he was
going to take the country back.
I said -- I said some pretty
And I'm not literally meaning take the country back, even though
that's almost what happened on January 6th.
I guess the question is, what is going through your mind where it's relevant to go
stolen, so what's the point of even going to D.C., is I guess what we're trying to figure out.
You said earlier you didn't think that the election had been
Well, as I said earlier, my -- you know, my hail season is kind of a seasonal
thing, and I hadn't been working.
People don't fix their cars that time of the year.
Because we decided to go to Washington because that's where Trump was, I
I wish I would've went to New York City now.
So President Trump played an impact in you wanting to come to
Then why didn't you go to New York City?
And you said other people were talking about going to January 6th around
Did you hear any of those conversations?
I just remember seeing stuff on Facebook.
on the phone to anybody really, I don't think.
Do you remember if what you saw on Face book was around December 12th
or was it later in December?
I didn't believe that that was on -- you know, I didn't know that we
were talking about going to January that early.
the election, but that's 3, 4 weeks, I guess.
I don't think that I talked
So I thought it was a week or two before
And I know you said you don't use Twitter a lot, but you did just answer Mr.
- ' s question by saying President Trump was a factor in going to Washington, D.C.
Do you remember former President Trump tweeting on December 19th about a wild
I never -- like I said, I never figured Twitter out, so I'm not on there.
I might've deleted it a while back.
But I never could figure out
Do you remember anyone else talking about a wild protest in D.C. on
So, on December 24, 2020 -- this is, again, from your docket -- you have a post on
social media, I think it's Facebook, where you said, quote, "Going to Washington DC with
Blakely to join the mob Jan 5th cmon join us."
Well, after I saw it, yes.
At that time, what did you think was happening
As I've said earlier, I thought it was going to be a handful of people going.
We were going to eat, drink, be merry, and maybe play some cards and go see Trump.
Then what did you mean by "mob"?
I didn't think we were going
with the mafia or anything like that.
No, but do you agree that "mob" can also mean a large group of people?
Do you agree that "mob" can also mean a large group of unruly people?
It can mean a whole lot of Italians, or it can mean a whole lot of soccer fans.
It could mean a lot of things, yes.
So doesn't "mob," doesn't that, though, insinuate something disorderly?
Well, it can insinuate a lot of things based on the context that you
M r - Well, you just said you weren't talking about the mafia.
"mob," as far as I know, is only a large group of unruly or disruptive people.
We've got a fishing mob that we go fishing with.
Well, when a bunch of us get together and go hunting, it's a mob.
M r . - So, when you go fishing, you say "I'm going out fishing with a mob
Well, I say that -- if somebody asks and I'm going with a mob,
which is three or four of my buddies, yes, I do say that.
M r . - But that's -- it's a very direct question.
about going fishing with your friends in Texas, you say, "I'm going out with my mob of
I actually say -- "Who are you fishing with?"
Is the mob a specific group of people?
Can you name -- is the mob the group of people that you were supposed to
So, then, how are you using "mob" in this context, then, if it's not
Well, as you said earlier, a mob can be just a group of people or it can be an
I think that I was saying -- I was using it in the context of a
I'm sorry if I misrepresented that.
beyond, sort of, the norms of society.
So why did you use that term?
A mob is -- unless I'm mistaken, a mob is
It is a specific adjective for a group of people that has moved
Well, I guess I didn't realize that that's all that it meant.
None of them would've gone to -- no.
I didn't intend that we were going to be necessarily with a
So who were you asking to join you?
Whoever was on Face book, I guess.
As I said earlier, I thought that it was going to be a group of people, that we
Why did you want them to join you?
were going to go and eat, drink, play some cards, and be merry.
forethought of going to be unruly or anything like that.
So you posted this on Facebook.
You wanted, sort of, anyone on Facebook
to come join you, or join the --
And you said President Trump brought you to Washington, D.C.
want people to come join you in some sort of protest for President Trump?
I wasn't really there to protest President Trump or -- you know, I just
generically put out -- I don't know if you have access to my Facebook, but I think, one day,
I put a recipe for barn owl out, and I didn't really want people to go shoot barn owls and
I'm kind of a smart aleck, as I said earlier.
joking and, you know, whimsical and out there.
a barn owl and then cook it.
A lot of my posts on Facebook are
I don't actually want people to go shoot
But you did want people to join you in Washington, D.C., or was that another
Well, no, I wanted some people to come.
Like I said earlier, you know, I
thought it was going to be a handful of friends that were going to come out there and --
So that was December 24th, that post.
looking at any websites or social media to find out information about what was
happening in Washington, D.C., on January 6th?
Did you know what was planned for Washington, D.C., on January 6th?
I had no idea, other than just going to be there.
Proud Boys or anti- -- any Black Lives Matter or any of those fringe, extremist groups at
Not even talking about those groups, but just generally, did you know there
would be a rally for former President Trump?
Well, before, you said you went to play cards, eat and drink, and be
So did you actually want people to come join you to do that or to go to the rally?
That's explicitly why I think we went there.
I think what I said earlier was we were going to eat, drink, be merry,
and go see Trump, I believe was exactly what I said.
So you first talk about going to Washington, D.C., on December 12th of 2020.
President Trump didn't even mention the rally on January 6th until December 19th of
So help us understand why you're coming to D.C. before it's even announced that
Well, somebody must have told me, because that's why I was
I don't know actually when it was announced or anything like that.
Do you know if your friend Blakely went to any political rallies before
I guess, because he's the one who told you on December 12th about the
So we're trying to figure out where you got the information about
So were you talking to him before you went to Washington, D.C.,
about what would happen in Washington, D.C.?
No, I don't think we ever discussed any plans of what was happening, other
I had no preconceived ideas or notions about anything that
When did you land -- or, sorry.
I believe it was in the evening, because I remember driving in in the Uber
and thinking it was kind of cool to see all those buildings.
When did you arrive in Washington, D.C.?
So, on January 5th, you posted another message, and I quote:
"Shit storm is coming but that's what the Democrats want."
Not other than being a smart aleck.
So can you explain that post?
So I understand that you're being a smart aleck, but there has to be a reason
So what information are you getting that is leading you to
Just something that came in my head.
I had no information other than just
Sometimes things come out of my mouth.
M r . - So, Mr. Conover, I'm just going to cut straight to the chase.
When we talk with folks, we use our common sense and ways of the world.
coming because that's what the Democrats want," that's not being a smart aleck, so what
I had no -- I don't know.
I don't know what I meant by that.
When you were talking to your friend Blakely, was he saying anything about
I can't recollect him saying anything like that.
said, like, there's joking, and then that's a very specific
thing to say as you arrive in a city to attend a political rally for a President contesting an
election with a lot of people.
And I'll just represent this to you.
You might not have been on social media, as
you say, but there was a lot of discussion about January 6th, as President Trump tweeted
So can you please try to remember, what gave you the sense that a shit storm was
And where did you get that idea?
Why did you think Democrats wanted whatever was coming?
I can't really answer that question.
I believe that people were going -- there was going to be a bunch of people
So, if you expected a bunch of people to be protesting, why did you
I know that the Democrats had been arguing against the Republicans, the
Republicans had been running -- arguing against them.
So I think it was more of an
I don't know why I used that
I don't really know what was going on
Was it an us-versus-them situation in regards to certifying the election?
I think it was Republicans against Democrats.
wouldn't have been -- I wouldn't have agreed to overturn an election.
don't believe the election was stolen from Trump.
I guess, we just don't understand this, right?
I think Trump's mouth cost him the
So, then, why are you coming to D.C.?
You're talking about a shit storm's
January 6th just happens to be the day that
None of this is adding up.
I don't know what to tell you, why it's not adding up.
there -- I don't know what to tell you.
I wish I wouldn't have gone.
That's different than why you went in the first place.
If you all pull up the statement of offense that we agreed to when
Mr. Conover took the plea -- and I'm trying to pull it up myself; give me one second -- and
you look at paragraph 8, that was a paragraph that myself and the prosecutor reworded
to state that the purpose of the defendant's trip to Washington, D.C., was to protest
Congress on the day Congress was certifying the electoral college vote.
The way that this sentence was originally phrased is to protest the certification of
the electoral college, which is not what Mr. Conover's purpose was for going to D.C.
purpose for going to D.C. is to protest Congress in general.
With that said, Paul, [inaudible] their questions.
I was going to say, as Ms. Wagner can appreciate, our
investigation is a little bit more expansive than the DOJ's, right?
necessarily tied to the statement of facts, though I do appreciate the way it's written.
We're just trying to have him explain it.
M r . - So thank you for pointing that out.
So, Paul, just answer their question as honestly as you can, okay?
They're trying to point me in a way that I'm not
I would like to say that we're not trying to point you in a certain way.
based on your statement of offense, you were there to protest Congress.
why you were there; you said to attend a rally for President Trump, to drink and be
we're trying to figure out why you were there.
None of those words involved "to protest Congress."
Were you there to protest Congress?
That I definitely was there for.
Why were you there to protest Congress specifically?
Because Congress hadn't been doing anything for the American people for
the last 4 years, other than arguing back and forth, Republicans and Democrats alike.
That's what I kind of alluded to earlier when I said I wish I wouldn't have said a shit
storm's coming for the Democrats, because it wasn't just the Democrats; it was the
Did you expect something to happen that day?
Nothing happened in Congress for 4 years.
there was a protest -- a rally -- sorry -- a rally for President Trump.
those people to also have your views about Congress?
No, I had -- everybody had a whole lot of different views about Congress, but
that was a big part of it.
I didn't hear a lot of people trying to overturn the election.
a matter of fact, a lot of people that I thought -- or that -- they thought that was one of
the dumbest things they'd ever heard too.
But you were there to protest Congress, both parties not doing
But you attended a rally for President Trump to contest the election.
So why did you expect that that protest was where -- why did you think that
I wouldn't have been behind trying to
protest was where you needed to be?
Again, I went there with no preconceived notions.
wasn't what I was doing, or that -- that wasn't on my mind.
So there might've been a lot of people there to go do that, but that
And this was implied, but, for the record, did you travel with your friend Blakely to
That's the first time I'd ever traveled with him or done anything in public
with him, as a matter of fact.
Did you drive there or fly there from Texas?
No, I stayed in the city at either a Hyatt or a Hilton.
And you said you arrived the night of January 5th.
And you drove there from Texas?
Do you remember if you stayed in the city itself or outside of the
rallies or anything going on on the night of January 5th?
We drove in and it was eerily quiet.
landmarks and just kind of being in awe.
Please let me -- you didn't see any protests at plazas or any
So, fair to say you did not expect there to be violence at the January 6th
That is very fair to say.
So let's talk about January 6th itself then.
You attended the rally at the Ellipse,
Do you remember about what time you got there?
I know that we got there, I believe, 11:30ish.
I don't -- no, I don't really
But before President Trump took the stage?
I think we got there right around the time he was getting there, because we
And you did listen -- you did hear him speak, then, correct?
I heard him speak for a while.
So was he the only speaker you wanted to see at the rally?
I had to go to the restroom, so at some point
I actually walked back to the hotel and went to the restroom and then came back.
So, when you were listening, do you remember this sentence:
fight like hell, you're not going to have a country anymore"?
I don't remember that specific sentence, no.
Do you remember that sort of sentiment about fighting for the country,
taking back the country, that kind of thing?
No, not really -- I mean, no.
Do you remember President Trump mentioning that attendees would march
to the Capitol and that he would join them?
I heard that later on, but I believe we headed out
Before we get to you leaving, were you talking to other people at the rally?
Do you remember what they were talking about or what they were focused
I talked to -- one of the other reasons that I was upset with Congress was all
the money that they were spending.
lady, and she professed to be at some university there, one of the -- I don't remember
which one she said it was, but she was some kind of professor of economics and, you
know, bills and things like that.
And I had a conversation with an older man and
And she kept asking me if I knew how much 1.2 trillion was, or 1.9 trillion, and I
said, "Yeah, that's a lot of money."
And, then, after asking me the same question two or
three times, I finally said, "Well, it's [inaudible]."
And, to make a long story short, she was talking about the bills in Congress, but
she said, "Did you know that if you had 10 -- if you had 10 bills and $1,000, how much
would each one of those bills get?"
but what if A only needed $50 and B needed $150?"
take the 50 that was left over from A and give it to B," and she goes, "No.
spend that $100, and B gets to go back and get more."
think, that $1.2 trillion isn't really $1.2 trillion, you know?
And I said, "Well, they would just
She was trying to explain to me, I
There was a lot of people that were talking about waste in Congress, stuff like
I mean, it was kind of like going to a, I don't know, State fair or something.
was all kinds of people saying all kinds of things.
Did anyone talk about Vice President Pence?
I didn't hear any of that until afterwards.
Anyone around you talk about the certification of the electoral college vote?
And do you remember President Trump talking about Vice President Pence
So you had some good economics lessons.
I don't remember that, but I wouldn't have agreed with that at all.
know, I feel maybe he was hurt that he lost the election, but, you know -- no, I didn't
And I disagree with it wholeheartedly.
Did you tell anybody around you or talk to anybody around you about how
you didn't believe the election was stolen?
I mean, you know, people have been -- they were talking
about stealing the election or voter fraud.
You know, there's been voter fraud in every
election since they've been putting paper ballots into a box.
So let's talk about why you decided to leave the rally early.
Did you already decide to go to the Capitol before you attended President Trump's
Do you remember how anybody responded if you did tell them that?
Nope, other than it was kind of cold.
And I think I had to go to the
Sorry to hear that, but -- so did you have a -- sorry, let me rephrase.
Why did you decide to go there after leaving the rally?
We actually went to the hotel, and we were watching the news, and we
could kind of see the mo- -- or, the crowd of people going towards the Capitol.
can't remember what time we headed that way, but we actually went from the hotel to
Why did you want to go to the Capitol at that point?
I just saw a bunch of people, and, you know, we decided to go.
preconceived notion or anything like that.
You're seeing a lot of people marching
Yeah, I wanted to go see what was going on.
Did you see any violence or hear of any reports of violence at that time?
I think when we were getting close to the Capitol I heard some police
officers talking about a fight on the -- I don't know if it was the east side or the west side,
where the inauguration was being held.
That's the west side, but did not expect you to know that --
-- off the top of your head.
